subject: Education
title: Censorship and Book Burning: When Literacy Threatens Power
description: A quick win: understand Censorship and Book Burning: When Literacy Threatens Power.

hook.text: The Nazis burned 25,000 books in one night. Every dictator knows: a reading public is a dangerous public.

buildup.text: Throughout history, rulers have banned books, imprisoned writers, and destroyed libraries to control ideas.

discovery.text: From Qin Dynasty China to apartheid South Africa, censorship targets literacy to suppress dissent.

twist.text: Banning a book often backfiresâ€”the 'Streisand effect' can make forbidden texts more popular than ever.

climax.text: UNESCO tracks press freedom globally; countries with less censorship consistently have higher literacy.

punchline.text: Those who burn books fear what literate people might think.

quiz.question: Why have authoritarian regimes historically targeted books and literacy?
options: A literate public can access dissenting ideas and challenge authority
Books were valuable and could be sold for profit
Regimes needed the paper for government documents
